title: How to kill someone with a ballpoint pen - Quora

response.answer_text: There are a number of ways you can kill someone with a ballpoint pen, the most obvious of which is just to stab a person with it over and over until he or she is dead. Done. But of course I usually answer questions because it gives me the opportunity to vaporize planets and that sort of thing. You know, the usual. So I thought I’d take a stab (see what I did there) at maximizing the devastation caused by just one ballpoint pen. A few rules first: the destruction must actually be caused by the pen, not the pen activating some other destructive device. You can’t press the nuclear launch button with the pen, and then claim the end of the world was caused by a pen. I’m willing to allow energy to be added to the pen, but that energy can’t be the source of the destruction either. Strapping the pen to the front of a train doesn’t cut it, but making the pen go fast is OK. But only the damage caused by the pen itself counts - no accelerating the pen to 0.999999c and then counting the fusion you create in front of the pen. So how much damage could be done with a pen? Well you could make the pen go really fast. If you did that, it could fly through several people if they were properly aligned. So right off the bat, you could kill more than one person with a pen. But this is probably limited to perhaps a dozen people or so - any more and the pen would just be obliterated. You could construct numerous blades from the pen, and with those probably increase your path of destruction to the hundreds of lives. These people would have to be willing to hold still while you ended their time here on Earth, but it would work. Can we go farther? Yes, though it’ll take some work. Ink chemistry Ink contains mostly chemicals that contain hydrogen, carbon, and oxygen. These chemicals are chosen for their color, obviously, but also for their non-toxicity. But we can rearrange the atoms in those molecules to make something far more toxic. The most toxic compound composed only of C, H, and O that I can find is: Digoxin - Wikipedia Digoxin has an LD50 of around 20mg/kg. It would take around 1.6 grams of Digoxin to kill an adult human. A Bic pen weighs around 5.8 grams, so you could make enough Digoxin (theoretically) to make around 3 fatal doses. But heavier pens could probably be used to poison dozens. And then there’s fusion. Most of a pen is C, H, and O. H would constitute roughly 10% of the mass, meaning a Bic pen would contain perhaps half a gram of hydrogen. When hydrogen is fused into helium, about 0.68% is converted directly into energy. 0.68% of half a gram of mass releases 306,000,000,000 J of energy. This is approximately equal to one of these: GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast - Wikipedia which is capable of killing thousands of people. If we fuse the carbon and hydrogen, we could increase the devastation even more. So is that it? Have we reached the limits of a pen’s destructive power? Sadly, no. Though these pens weren’t all ballpoint pens, I think you’ll appreciate the similarities: A pen was used to write the words that have been used to kill millions. A pen was used to codify slavery into the US Constitution. A pen was used to write Mein Kampf. A pen signed the order to bomb Hiroshima and Nagasaki. A pen authorized the use of Agent Orange. A pen was used to sign the flight school applications for the 9/11 bombers. Even when it’s me answering the question, the pen is mightier than the sword. Converting a Bic directly to energy kills thousands. But using a pen to turn violent thoughts and hateful ideologies into written words can kill millions.
